content.description: Classic and super fun moves on good edges up a face to a fun bulge finish. Good holds and enjoyable movement the entire way up. Needs a new first hanger at this time (missing, but has nut and washer on the bolt. First bolt is easily bypassed by starting just right, or stick clipping the 2nd bolt.
content.location: About the middle of the developed part of the cliff. Scramble up a couple of easy steps to the base, just right of a tree growing above the trail.

climbs.name: Wyde Syde
climbs.fa: FFA 6/4/11 Bill Coe, Ujahn Davisson, Chad Ellars

content.description: A fun off-width that is a good introduction to the world of wide.
content.protection: Pro to 2 including two C3 #00.  A 12 Valley Giant for the start is optional.

content.description: If arête climbing is your thing, you'll love this good route. Strike up the finger crack to the roof, pull over it and follow the arête through a few airy clips and balancey moves to a committing mantel finish (easier than it looks, but still heady).
content.protection: 6 bolts - Shared anchor with a 5.10c face climb on the left, and a 2 bolt 5.12a squeeze job face climb between the two 5.10s.
content.location: Right at the corner where the cliff takes a sharp turn right when walking along the cliff.

content.description:
Pull solid moves getting up and over the right side of the roof, and then cruise up to a crux move merging into Progressive Climax.

2nd bolt location is very odd (wrong side of the roof), and makes for a awkward clip. Best to climb past it, and then reach down to clip, or clip the next bolt, or stick clip the 2nd bolt from the ground.

climbs.name: Slow Dance
climbs.fa: FFA June 6, 2011 Chad Ellars, Bill Coe

content.description: Jam up the sweet hand-crack located in a shallow dihedral. A small pedestal allows for a rest once the crack ends. Angling slightly right onto the face via a sequential blend of side-pulls, smearing, and crimps will get you near the top. If you’ve made it this far, a mantel move below the anchor won’t throw you for a loop.
Cruxy at the start with technical stemming, the route quickly gives way to excellent and consistent stemming to the anchor. Well worth doing!
content.protection: 6 bolts? Anchor with rap rings for lowering

content.description: This awesome route has a bit of a tricky start transitioning to amazing edges up the face and dihedral, traversing right to an enjoyable arête finish featuring jugs to the anchor. Longest route at Rock Creek at this time.
content.protection: 8-9 bolts? Anchor with quick-links only, rap to avoid twisting your rope

climbs.name: Pearl Jam
climbs.fa: Chad Ellars, Bill Coe, Tim Olson

content.description:
Sweet hand and foot jams up the first 20', then cut hard left into the wide flare of Northern Pearl and finish to the top.

Continuing straight up from the crack into the bolt line is 5.10a.
Fun fingers crack at the start, leading into a wide flare, and then face holds and finger locks to the top and shared anchor.
content.protection: couple finger size cams or nuts, and then a 2" or 3" cam for the flare, and then a couple medium nuts for the top half.
content.location: Last route on the trail, about 20' after the trail comes around the cliff corner.

content.description: Starts with a mantle onto a ledge before following a crack with good edges on the faces for hands and stemming, with the occasional jam. Another, smaller ledge before the finish sets you up to place a hand-sized cam before getting into 6-8 feet of the best hand jamming at the crag!
content.protection: Singles in BD 0.5-3 with extensions will safely protect this one. Save your #2 for the finish!

content.description: Great stemming feet with poor locks and jams off the ground. Climbing eases as edges become available for holds. A wide crack with a finger crack inside it guards the layback finish.
content.protection: Single rack from BD 0.3 to 4. Small stoppers optional.

content.description: Starts with a big crack that only gets mossier. Thankfully, there are bolts for the finish.
Starts with a short hand crack that gets you on top of the ledge. From there, follow the offwidth/squeeze chimney up the bolt line to the finish!
content.protection: a single hand-sized cam will get you to the ledge, 5 bolts, anchor chains

content.description: Starts with a wide finger crack that narrows before disappearing into a seam. Tricky, balancey face/arête/pocket climbing and stemming ensues, with the usual Rock Creek mantle finish.
content.protection: small gear - BD 0.3-0.75 and stoppers; Ball Nuts optional but encouraged, two bolts

climbs.name: Bottle Rocket
climbs.fa: FFA: 4th of July, 2011 by Chad Ellars & Bill Coe

content.description: Bottle Rocket shares the start and first bolt with Inner Sanctum but avoids the off-width by angling right onto a fun and exciting face. A final perplexing move will put you at the anchor which is shared by The Watchman.
content.protection: Quickdraws and a #2 Camalot for the beginning

content.description: Fun climbing through the first three bolts gets you to the meat of the route. Some trickery will get you through the short crux, then enjoy easier climbing to the chains.

This route features a fun, and slightly tricky start up edges to a interesting and unique slab crux. While the upper half looks mossy, all the holds you need are clean.

Alternate finish goes left into the top half of Pladtastic crack, just above the roof at the 3rd or 4th bolt and goes at 5.8, gear to 2".
